comment.author: 27398485@N08
comment._content: The Small rock cut temple was built (one of two side by side) by Ramses II, 19th dynasty, (1314-1224 B.C.) honoring the Gods Amun Ra (Amon Re) and Re Horakhte, near Aswan. In 1966 to 1968, they were cut away from the rock face in large pieces, moved to higher ground and reassembled, to save them from the rising water level, due to the Aswan Dam. Statues are 67 feet tall. Scale evident in contrast to seated man in center of image. near duplicate image found here: oi.uchicago.edu/museum/collections/pa/breasted/sites.html From Breasted Expeditions to Egypt & Sudan in 1905-1906. Temple honors Ramses' wife - Nefertari, and goddess Hathor, wife of Horus, love, joy, goddess of the desert, and turquoise mines(!). www.ancientegypt.co.uk/gods/explore/main.html Statues are 33 ft tall, smaller ones are of royal family members - Attribution reads: "Ramses II, he has made a temple, excavated in the mountain, of eternal workmanship, for the chief queen Nefertari, beloved of Mu, in Nubia, forever and ever, Nefertari for whose sake the very sun does shine." www.touregypt.net/featurestories/abusimbel.htm scale evident by men at entrance
